oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Latin for Girls

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. S. A. Vaughan sets forth to address those who deem Latin for girls unnecessary. This four-column argument contains a pencil notation at the top that designates its physical location in the Tennessee Historical Society holdings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides
Broadsides; Latin language; Authors; Nashville (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vaughan, Mrs. S. A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. S. A. Vaughan was a noted educator. As she indicates in the broadside, though raised locally, she spent time in New York and had twenty years of teaching experience by this date. She authored volumes of readers and spellers that would be published in Atlanta during the Civil War period. She and her contemporary female-teachers-turned-authors, however, were not responsible for any upper level Confederate textbooks.
